snippet: College basketball coaches and analysts say that having experienced players and practicing end-of-game situations can help a team’s results in close contests.
abstract: Advanced basketball analysts factor in what they refer to as luck statistic, calculation that accounts for results of close games played by teams whose games are not all close; several coaches of both lucky and unlucky college teams say tracking the statistic can be meaningful if it's used to guide end-of-game strategies like making more plays out of timeouts and more deliberate fouls.
lead_paragraph: College basketball coaches and analysts say that having experienced players and practicing end-of-game situations can help a team’s results in close contests.

headline.main: Better to Be Lucky Than Good? Sometimes It’s True
headline.print_headline: Better to Be Lucky Than Good? Sometimes It’s True
